frege.runtime

Class Fun8<X>

    public abstract class Fun8<X>
extends Lambda

    Frege functions with arity 8.

    See Fun1 for a general discussion of untyped function values.

    • Method Detail

      • apply

        public final Fun7<X> apply(java.lang.Object arg1)

        Apply this function to an argument.

        This method creates an instance of Fun7 that collects the remaining arguments and, when evaluated, invokes the eval(java.lang.Object, java.lang.Object, java.lang.Object, java.lang.Object, java.lang.Object, java.lang.Object, java.lang.Object, java.lang.Object) method of this class.

        Parameters:
        arg1 - the argument
        Returns:
        an instance of type Fun7 that waits for the remaining arguments to be supplied and calls back with all arguments.

      • apply

        public final Delayed apply(java.lang.Object arg1,
            java.lang.Object arg2,
            java.lang.Object arg3,
            java.lang.Object arg4,
            java.lang.Object arg5,
            java.lang.Object arg6,
            java.lang.Object arg7,
            java.lang.Object arg8)

        Apply this function to all its arguments at once.

        This method creates an instance of Delayed that, when evaluated, invokes the eval(java.lang.Object, java.lang.Object, java.lang.Object, java.lang.Object, java.lang.Object, java.lang.Object, java.lang.Object, java.lang.Object) method of this function.

        Use of this method is preferrable compared to repeated invokation of the single argument form since intermediate closure creation is saved.
        Returns:
        an instance of type Delayed

      • toSuper

        public final <B,Y extends B> Fun8<B> toSuper(Fun8<Y> it)

        Force the Java typechecker to accept sensible substitutions.

        The Java typechecker won't accept a function that promisses to return X in place of a function that promises to return Object, though this should be completely save, shouldn't it?

        It also refuses to accept any frege type, when Lazy is demanded, though every frege type implements Lazy.

        Returns:
        This function, now promising to return a broader type

      • eval

        public abstract X eval(java.lang.Object arg8,
     java.lang.Object arg7,
     java.lang.Object arg6,
     java.lang.Object arg5,
     java.lang.Object arg4,
     java.lang.Object arg3,
     java.lang.Object arg2,
     java.lang.Object arg1)

        Run the function.

        This method will be called by the Fun7.eval(java.lang.Object, java.lang.Object, java.lang.Object, java.lang.Object, java.lang.Object, java.lang.Object, java.lang.Object) method of the object resulting from this.apply(...). It actually performs computation and returns a result.

        Functions always return the announced type (which can be a lazy).

        This method must be implemented by all subclasses.

        Note that the arguments must be passed in reverse order. The reason is that in this way the byte code for any intermediate closure will only have to push its argument and invoke the next higher closure's eval method. A reordering of the arguments on the stack will not be needed. This could save a substantial amounts of memory writes (I hope).

        Returns:
        result
